experience: You and Carol both know Raoul Encinas, Carolyn Sechler, and 26 others

At FreeUp Web Studio, we offer affordable website options to small and medium sized business with ongoing support and management of the website. In my work as co-owner of FreeUp Web Studio, I work with clients to solidify their website needs and create a strategy to meet those website goals. Once the goals have been established, we design and develop the web solution and then continue to manage that website for the client. My favorite thing about my work is working with new clients and helping their vision of a new website become a reality.

Tech Tools, LLC works with small businesses and non-profits in website development and implementation primarily using WordPress.  Tech Tools has a network of strategic partners that also bring expertise in the area of marketing writing, and brand development to the content portions of the website.  One of the greatest barriers to the efficient use of technology is the lack of knowledge.  Tech Tools, LLC is also available for speaking engagements and training for organizations regarding their overall technology strategic plan.  Tech Tools can work with you to create in-person, online and recorded training materials specially designed for individual organizations and groups.
Served as Adjunct Professor teaching bachelor level social work courses including, "Social Service Delivery Systems".
National Association of Social Workers, AZ

Served as chief executive of the association in charge of day to day operations including the recruitment, training, and partnership with Board of Directors and volunteer leadership to implement the activities consistent with the overall mission, goals and objectives.  A key responsibility included the fiscal planning and expenditure of resources making certain that all activities were in line with the overall goals of the association.Some key succeses and outcomes achieved during my tenure at NASW include the ability to increased the chapter financial reserves by 100% in the first six years of employment.  While at NASW-AZ, the chapter dramatically increased chapter continuing education offerings by over 350% from one conference per year offering 475 units of service to a comprehensive continuing education series offered around the state with over 1,800 units of service annually.  During my time of service, the chapter was regarded as one of the more technologically advanced chapters in the association.  During this time, there were continual chapter website improvement as well as the implementation of online reporting, storage and accountability systems for volunteers.

As the Executive Director of Health Care Access, I served as the chief executive of the organization in charge of day to day operations.  This included working closely with the Board of Directors to achieve agency goals and objectives.  Personnel management was an important part of the role as I worked to recruit, supervise and manage the organization's volunteer and paid staff.  As chief executive, I was also responsible for the budgeting and planning for the needs of the organization including resource acquisition, fund-raising, grant writing, and the recruitment of volunteers and donated services

Carol Stambaugh is an exceptional leader. I have had the privilege to see her in action during her term as President of the Arizona Society of Association Executives. Her term as President coincided with my tenure on the AZSAE board of directors. She is energetic, bright and focused on making her organization and her community stronger. I highly recommend Carol as one of the top leaders that I have ever had the pleasure to work with. She is a true agent of positive change, and a tremendously valued friend and collegue.

summary: Having started as a social worker and then working as an Executive Director in non-profit organizations, I appreciate the challenges faced by non-profits and small businesses. As a result, my primary focus is designing website and web based solutions for small businesses and non-profits.
